pr_title: Update the reactive database client extensions to use Mutiny

timeline.bodyText: I believe the volatile construct was preferred here because the producer can be invoked concurrently at runtime (e.g. in request scoped beans). Using synchronization instead would serialize these calls. Or am I missing something?
timeline.author: tsegismont

replies.bodyText:
I actually want the serialization here to catch the creation of the deprecated clients.
I can restore using a volatile for the PgPool but that mix 2 synchronization constructs.
replies.author: cescoffier

timeline.message:
Add Mutiny support to the reactive PostgreSQL extension

* Expose the Mutiny PgPool
* Deprecate the RX and Axle API
* Use lazy instantiation
* Change the synchronization protocol for the PgPool

For the main pool, use volatile instead of being guarded by a lock.
This is because the "set" is called at start time, and then there is no concurrent writes.
Other objects are guarded as we don't do atomic actions on them.

Add Mutiny support to the reactive MySQL extension

* Expose the Mutiny MySQLPool
* Deprecate the RX and Axle API
* Use lazy instantiation
* Change the synchronization protocol for the PgPool

Use volatile instead of being guarded by a lock for the main pool.
This is because the "set" is called at start time, and then there is no concurrent writes.
The other pools are guarded because we don't do atomic actions on them (check and set).

Switch reactive ITs client to mutiny

This commit uses the Mutiny PG/MySQL Pools instead of the Axle ones.

timeline.bodyText: How about using AtomicReference to remove synchronization without losing the checks in the producer methods?
timeline.author: tsegismont

replies.bodyText: AtomicReference.compareAndSet(null, instance) requires the instance to be already created - so it's not lazy. Using updateAndGet could work but is rather convoluted (you would need to move the if check in the binary operator).
replies.author: cescoffier

replies.bodyText: Ok, let's revisit later if that proves to be a problem
replies.author: tsegismont
